Writing LaTeX Locally on macOS

Posted by Wanyu Zhang on May 1, 2025

Previously, I used Overleaf to write .tex files. It‚Äôs convenient, beginner-friendly, and great for collaboration. However, it only works online, which means you can‚Äôt draft your paper on a flight (maybe it‚Äôs a good thing). That‚Äôs why I‚Äôve started transitioning to writing and compiling .tex files locally on macOS.

This post is a collection of helpful resources for setting up a local LaTeX environment.

Introductory LaTeX resources

There are some excellent beginner-friendly Chinese docs:

  • A quick guide on LaTeX syntax from OI-wiki
  • A more approachable blog from Liam Huang

(Here I‚Äôd like to recommend Liam Huang‚Äôs blog on LaTeX, where you can find almost everything you need to know!)

More comprehensive official documentation in English:

  • LaTeX2e: An unofficial reference manual
  • Learn LaTeX tutorial (available in many languages)

Getting started

To set up a local LaTeX environment similar to Overleaf, you‚Äôll need:

  • TeX distribution: This is the core engine and format bundle. On macOS, people usually use MacTeX (a TeX Live distribution for Mac).
  • Editor: You can use the default TeXShop editor or other text/code editors like VS Code or Sublime Text.

Let‚Äôs go through the installation step-by-step.

Install TeX Live (MacTex)

Be prepared ‚Äî downloading MacTeX can take a few hours, so it‚Äôs often better to use mirror sites.

  • TeX Live (Windows): Official
  • MacTeX (Macs): Official , SJTU mirrors

Reference: Installation guide in Chinese by Liam Huang

Install editors

For a quick start, you can launch TeXShop, which comes with MacTeX. You‚Äôll see a simple blank window ‚Äî this is your editor. Insert a LaTeX template, click compile, and the resulting PDF appears in a separate window. Clean and elegant, right?

If this default setup works for you, great! You‚Äôre all set. However, if you want more features or flexibility, you can try other editors like VS Code or Sublime Text.

VS Code configuration

You can follow this tutorial to configure VS Code. However, I encountered a couple of issues during setup. Here‚Äôs how I resolved them:

  1. chktex could not be found warning

Solution: Disable the linter by adding this to your settings.json:

"latex.linter.enabled": false
  1. Error: spawn pdflatex ENOENT

This indicates the LaTeX binary isn‚Äôt found. Add the correct environment path to your settings.json (specific to macOS):

"latex-workshop.latex.tools": [
  {
    "name": "pdflatex",
    "command": "pdflatex",
    "args": [
      "-synctex=1",
      "-interaction=nonstopmode",
      "-file-line-error",
      "%DOC%"
    ],
    // Start: newly added
    "env": {
      "PATH": "/Library/TeX/texbin:/usr/local/bin:/opt/homebrew/bin:${env:PATH}"
    }
    // End: newly added
  }
],

üîß Make sure to set the environment path for each tool (e.g., pdflatex, xelatex, latexmk) under latex-workshop.latex.tools.

With all problems settled down, the compiler should work smoothly. The result looks quite polished:

Sublime Text configuration

I hadn‚Äôt used Sublime Text before writing this post, but it seems to be a powerful and customizable editor. I‚Äôm looking forward to exploring it further.

Helpful guides I used:

  • Sublime Text installation and introduction (Chinese)
  • Sublime Text + LaTex for Windows (Chinese)
  • Sublime Text + LaTex for Windows (EN/CH)
  • Sublime Text + LaTex for Macs (EN/CH)

After following the instructions, your setup will look like this:
